Box 124, Blindern, N-0314 Oslo, Norway Received 11 July 1996; accepted 25 September 1996 Abstract Platinum-alumina catalysts were prepared at 20 by using a method in which hexachlor- oplatinic anions from solution were adsorbed on 0-alumina in the pH range 1-10 and with contact times between 1 and 24 h. An adsorption maximum was observed at pH around 3-4. From measurements of electrophoretic mobility, the isoelectric point of 0-alumina was determined to be about 8.5. Comparison with literature data indicated that "f- and 0-alumina exhibit similar adsorption properties and that the amount of Pt deposited is controlled by pH and contact time for both systems. The adsorption appears to proceed initially as a physisorption process with relatively strong specific interaction or chemisorption taking over at longer contact times. Pt/0-alumina samples with 0.3 to 2.2 wt% Pt were prepared. Wet calcination at 570 led to a decrease in the C1 content of the samples, while the Pt content was unaffected. 1. Introduction The importance of the pH of the precursor solution in the preparation of Pt/y- alumina catalysts is well known [ 1-3]. The amount of Pt adsorbed on the y-alumina surface appears to reach a maximum around pH=4, while it decreases and approaches zero as the pH approaches y-alumina's isoelectric point (pH =7-9 [3]). The main purpose of this study was to investigate the adsorption properties of 0- alumina for the hexachloroplatinic complex, with the objective to optimize the preparation of Pt/A1203 dehydrogenation catalysts. 0-alumina was chosen because of its high hydrothermal stability, which makes it suitable for use as a carrier material under reaction conditions such as hydrocarbon dehydrogenation. 0-A1203 was further an interesting subject for this kind of research, since little literature is published about metal impregnation on this carder. * Corresponding author. Olsbye et al./Applied Catalysis A: General 152 (1997) 127-141 To facilitate comparison with y-A1203, the impregnation method followed a literature procedure for impregnation of Pt on y-AI203.0-alumina differs from y- alumina in that it has a lower specific surface area. Both structures are spinel related, but in "/-A1203 both tetrahedral and octahedral sites are occupied, whereas in 0-alumina only octahedral sites are occupied [4]. The surface of ),-alumina is nearly completely covered by OH- groups, while in 0-alumina, nearly all the water is expelled, and the surface consists almost exclusively of 02- anions and anion vacancies. Due to the surface protons, y-alumina has some BrCnsted acidity in addition to Lewis acidity, while 0-alumina has Lewis acidity only [5]. In aqueous medium however, both phases develop fully hydrated surfaces. 2. Experimental Two support materials were studied for adsorption of platinum. Pt-complexes in solution HzPtC16(aq) exists in different forms depending on solution pH [6,7]. From pH 1.3-8.3 different monovalent chloroplatinum complexes dominate. At pH >8.3 the divalent complex PtC14(OH)22- dominates and at pH < 1.3 the uncharged complex HzPtC16 is the major species [1]. Results and discussion The components of our system are initially solid alumina and water with dissolved, partly dissociated hexachloroplatinic acid. In the combined system the alumina surface becomes positively charged by adsorption of H+ from the acidic solution. As a result of the surface charge, the chloro- platinic anionic complex is then partly adsorbed onto this positively charged surface. 134 U. Olsbye et al./Applied Catalysis A." General 152 (1997) 127-141 5.1. The Al203 carriers Electrophoretic mobility of 0-alumina particles in solutions of 0.001M and 0.1M NaC1 were measured (Fig. 3). The electrophoretic mobility is a function of the charge density at the shear plane a few water layers beyond the solid-liquid interface (Fig. 2) and is thus related to the number of potential adsorption sites for ions of opposite charge, but it also depends on ionic strength and nature of ions in solution [9,10]. From Fig. 3 the isoelectric point of 0-alumina was determined to be about 8.5. This value was adopted as its "zero point of charge" (zpc) falling within the 7-9 range of zpc-values reported for alumina oxides and hydoxides in the literature [3,11 ]. The observed increase in electrophoretic mobility with a decrease in the salt concentration is in accordance with the theory of diffuse double layers, because the charge compensating counter ions on the average come closer to the surface as the salt concentration increases [8,10]. Dissolution of the alumina and the adsorption of dissolved species onto the alumina surface start immediately when the alumina is dispersed in the aqueous solution of the acidic hexachloroplatinum complex. The time needed for equili- bration between the solid aluminas and the solution depends on the type of alumina. Furrer and Stumm [12] studied the dissolution kinetics of 6-alumina in aqueous solution at pH =2.5-6.0. They found a maximum dissolution rate at pH <3.5, that is: 10-s mol h-1 m-2. For pH =2.5-4.3, the dissolution rate was constant during 40 h experiments. In our study of 0-aluminas, the surface reactions including alumina dissolution appear to be fast enough to reach an apparently stable situation within 24 h. Although we lack evidence that slow alumina dissolution does not take place after this, we have chosen to refer to this situation as equilibrium. \ E 6- 4- 3- 2 I- 0 -1 3- 42 F I1~ .... ~_. Chemisorption: Ligand exchange In a chemisorption process, ions may adsorb on a surface with the opposite or the same charge, in the latter case increasing the effective charge at the surface. However, physisorption will generally take place at the same time. Several groups have proposed that the adsorption of chloroplatinum complex and/or chloride ions on alumina proceeds as a chemisorption process [3,13,14,16]. The results pre- sented here support the proposal that the Pt-Cl-species are chemisorbed on 0- alumina, since the Pt and C1 adsorption exceeded the calculated surface charge in the pH-range 4-10. The amounts adsorbed at pH=8 after 24 h exceeded the calculated surface charge by a factor 3-5, but it must be noted that, although the overall charge at zpc is zero, both positively and negatively charged surface functional groups coexist, and that the positively charged groups may well be responsible for the observed adsorption of Pt-Cl-species at pH=8. Indications of a combined fast physisorption-slow chemisorption process is found in Fig. 4 where reversible Pt adsorption was observed in one of the experiments with a pH change from 7 to 8 after 4 h contact time, while prolonged contact (22-24 h) led to significant readsorption. If chemisorption of Pt--Cl-species takes place this is not likely to happen with the PtC16-complex as such, but rather through an oxygen bridge with ligand exchanged complex ions. It is interesting to note that occurence of PtC16-complexes decrease from 90% to 10% of all complex ions in the pH-range 2-4, that is the range in which adsorption increases steaply with pH after 70 min contact time. This observation may suggest that chemisorption via OH-ligands or oxygen bridges would be important, although we lack direct evidence. 5.4. Comparison between 7- and O-A1203 0-A1203(a) was impregnated with Pt using 70 min contact time and a final pH = 1-8. The amount of Pt adsorption per unit area after 70 min contact time over 0- A1203(a) and 0-A1203(b) in this study, as well as that obtained for 7-A1203 in [1], are compared in Fig. 6a. Fig. 6b and c show the corresponding A1 dissolution and pH changes, respectively, for the three series. These results show that the amount of Pt adsorption was similar for the three series. It is evident that the A1 dissolution and pH change also followed the same trend for the three series. At equilibrium the concentration of A1 dissolved from a specific Al-phase should be determined only by the pH, the concentration of complexing ions and the ionic strength. Comparison of our data with the solubility of aluminas indicate that our solutions are undersaturated with A1 below pH around 4 (Fig. 6b). At pHinitial=2.2 (i.e., no NaOH or HC1 addition), the two 0-aluminas differ greatly in A1 dissolution and Pt adsorption after 70 rain contact time, in spite of having quite similar XRD and BET properties. This observation strongly suggests that the results obtained at pH below 4 (where the A1 solubility is high) are dominated by the kinetics of A1 dissolution for a specific alumina batch. A 140 U. Conclusions It can be concluded that hexachloroplatina complex anions are specifically adsorbed on the surface of aluminas at pH >4. At pH <4 the alumina is highly soluble, and the results are not relevant for equilibrium situations. A maximum adsorption of Pt is achieved at a pH around 4 with contact times of 24 h or more. T- and 0-alumina were found to exhibit similar adsorption properties towards the hexachloroplatinic complex. 7. coredata.dc:description: Platinum-alumina catalysts were prepared at 20°C by using a method in which hexachloroplatinic anions from solution were adsorbed on θ-alumina in the pH range 1–10 and with contact times between 1 and 24 h. An adsorption maximum was observed at pH around 3–4. From measurements of electrophoretic mobility, the isoelectric point of θ-alumina was determined to be about 8.5. Comparison with literature data indicated that γ- and θ-alumina exhibit similar adsorption properties and that the amount of Pt deposited is controlled by pH and contact time for both systems. The adsorption appears to proceed initially as a physisorption process with relatively strong specific interaction or chemisorption taking over at longer contact times. Pt θ -alumina samples with 0.3 to 2.2 wt% Pt were prepared. Wet calcination at 570°C led to a decrease in the Cl content of the samples, while the Pt content was unaffected.
